choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A new combined treatment regimen of chemotherapy and immunotherapy has significantly increased survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. If the number of new cases remains consistent, but patients live longer, which epidemiological impact would be observed? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • Due to the new drug combination, patient survival rates have risen, resulting in a situation where the incidence remains unchanged while prevalence sees an increase.

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Since New cases will keep on occurring at the same rate, Incidence will remain same. Duration will increase (as survival increases). So, overall Prevalence will increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When patient survival increases due to a new treatment, the incidence of the disease remains the same, but the prevalence increases due to longer survival duration.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in fetal growth?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth hormone

 

Growth hormone (GH) does not play a significant role in fetal growth. The primary regulators of fetal growth are insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and thyroxine. IGFs are critical for cellular growth and differentiation during fetal development. Thyroxine, a thyroid hormone, is essential for brain development and overall growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factors: These play a crucial role in fetal growth by promoting cellular growth and differentiation.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: This hormone is vital for proper development, particularly for brain development and metabolic regulation.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because growth hormone does not significantly influence fetal growth, while IGFs and thyroxine do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, while insulin-like growth factors and thyroxine are crucial for proper fetal development.

questions.text: During a major disaster response, the medical team in an emergency department needs to prioritize patients based on the severity of their injuries and their medical needs. This prioritization process is known as triage. Each patient is assigned a specific color code representing their current state and the urgency of their medical attention. Which of the following correctly matches the color designation with its corresponding level of patient priority in the triage process? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Green – ambulatory

 

  • Triage is a critical process used in emergency medicine to quickly classify patients according to the severity of their health condition and the urgency of their need for care.
  • The color-coding system is a standardized approach used globally, with each color representing a specific category of priority:
  • Green indicates "ambulatory" patients, who are those with relatively minor injuries or conditions that do not require immediate, life-saving intervention.
  • These patients can often walk and may have injuries such as infections, closed fractures, minor abrasions, and lacerations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

choices.text: Village Health Planning and Management Committee
Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

questions.text: As part of a health development project in rural India, you're asked about the key community group responsible for overseeing local health, sanitation, and nutrition initiatives. Which committee best fits this description? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

 

  • One of the key elements of the National Rural Health Mission is the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition committee (VHSNC).
  • The committee has been formed to take collective actions on issues related to health and its social determinants at the village level.
  • They are particularly envisaged as being central to ‘local level community action’ under NRHM, which would develop to support the process of Decentralized Health Planning.
  • Thus VHSNC is envisaged to take leadership in providing a platform for improving health awareness and access of community for health services, address specific local needs and serve as a mechanism for community based planning and monitoring.
  • The committee is formed at the revenue village level and it should act as a sub-committee of the Gram Panchayat.
  • It should have a minimum of 15 members which should comprise of elected member of the Panchayat who shall lead the committee, all those working for health and health related services should participate, community members/ beneficiaries and representation from all community sub-groups especially the vulnerable sections and hamlets/ habitations. ASHA residing in the village shall be the member secretary and convener of the committee.

 

 ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 

 

  • Create awareness about nutritional issues and significance of nutrition as an important determinant of health.
  • Carry out survey on nutritional status and nutritional deficiencies in the village especially among women and children.
  • Identify locally available food stuffs of high nutrient value as well as disseminate and promote best practices (traditional wisdom) congruent with local culture, capabilities and physical environment through a process of community consultation.
  • Inclusion of Nutritional needs in the Village Health Plan – The committee will do an in-depth analysis of causes of malnutrition at the community and household levels, by involving the ANM, AWW, ASHA and ICDS Supervisors.
  • Monitoring and Supervision of Village Health and Nutrition Day to ensure that it is organized every month in the village with the active participation of the whole village.
  • Facilitate early detection of malnourished children in the community; tie up referral to the nearest Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC) as well as follow up for sustained outcome.
  • Supervise the functioning of Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village and facilitate its working in improving nutritional status of women and children.
  • Act as a grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panchayat Health Committee and Option B. Village Health Planning and Management Committee generally refer to broader terms, but they do not specifically target the integrated approach of the VHSNC.

 

Option C. Rogi Kalyan Samiti (Patient Welfare Committee) / Hospital Management Committee is a simple yet effective management structure. This committee, a registered society, acts as a group of trustees for the hospitals to manage the affairs of the hospital. It consists of members from local Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), NGOs, local elected representatives and officials from Government sector who are responsible for proper functioning and management of the hospital / Community Health Centre / FRUs. RKS / HMS is free to prescribe, generate and use the funds with it as per its best judgement for smooth functioning and maintaining the quality of services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VHSNC plays a crucial role in the grassroots-level health planning and implementation in rural India, ensuring that health initiatives are tailored to the specific needs and conditions of the community.
  • It is a vital part of the health ecosystem, facilitating a comprehensive approach to public health management in rural settings.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichothiodystrophy

 

The given clinical image of hair seen under polarizing microscopy reveals tiger tail banding (alternating light and dark bands) characteristic of trichothiodystrophy.

 

Trichothiodystrophy/PIBIDS syndrome: Autosomal Recessive condition

 

  • Photosensitivity (unlike XP, has NO increased skin cancer risk)
  • Ichthyosis
  • Brittle hair (short/sparse on scalp/brows/lashes w/alternating light and dark bands on polarizing light microscopy (“tiger-tail” abnormality)
  • Intellectual impairment and ataxia
  • Decreased fertility/hypogonadism
  • Short stature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichorrhexis nodosa: It is associated with node formation. It may be seen in arginosuccinic aciduria. Characterized by classical appearance as if two paint brushes are rubbing against each other described as Thrust Paintbrush appearance.

 

 

Option B. Trichorrhexis invaginata: Also known as Bamboo hair having Golf tee or Ball & Socket appearance, is characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. Seen in Netherton’s syndrome.

 

 

Option D: Monilethrix: Beaded hair seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Tiger tail" banding of hair under polarized light microscopy is indicative of trichothiodystrophy, a condition characterized by brittle hair with reduced sulfur content and potentially associated with multisystem involvement.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 1537

Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th edition Volume III Pages 68.19, 78.10 89.53-54

questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Moribund patients receive the lowest priority

 

In Triage, these patients are given different color coding as mentioned below –

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

questions.text: The following image depicts: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Production of monoclonal antibodies

 

The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

 

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

 

 

The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.

 

Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell lines for viral culture: This option is incorrect as the process depicted is not related to culturing cells for viral growth, but rather for antibody production.

 

Option C. Vaccine synthesis: This option is incorrect because vaccine synthesis generally involves the creation of attenuated or inactivated pathogens or their components, not the production of monoclonal antibodies.

 

Option D. Process of genetic engineering: This option is incorrect as genetic engineering involves manipulating an organism's genes directly, whereas the process depicted is about producing antibodies through hybridoma technology.

 

Educational Objective:


The process depicted in the images is the production of monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma technology.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The patient's clinical features are strongly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45XO), a condition characterized by:

 

  • Widely spaced nipples: Shield chest appearance.
  • Webbed neck: Due to congenital lymphedema.
  • Tanner grade 1 breast development: Indicates no breast development.
  • Streak ovaries on ultrasound: Ovaries that are underdeveloped and nonfunctional.
  • Hormonal profile: Raised FSH and LH due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries, and reduced estradiol indicating ovarian failure.

 

Other clinical features of Turner syndrome include short stature, primary amenorrhea, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies. The syndrome results in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallmann syndrome: It is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), not hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: 46XY karyotype with female external genitalia, well-developed breasts, absent axillary and pubic hair, and gonads are testes, not streak ovaries.

 

Option D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome: Mullerian agenesis, where secondary sexual characters are present but the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina are absent. This syndrome does not present with webbed neck or widely spaced nipples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 441

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: Which scoring system is used to assess the severity of wound infections and is commonly utilized in research and surveillance? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Southampton grading scale

 

The Southampton grading scale is specifically designed to evaluate surgical site infections (SSIs). This scale is valuable in both research and surveillance contexts because it helps differentiate between major and minor wound infections. Major SSIs involve significant pus discharge or require a secondary procedure for drainage and may present systemic signs like tachycardia, pyrexia, and raised WBC count. Minor wound infections might discharge pus or infected serous fluid without causing excessive discomfort or systemic signs. The Southampton scale helps in auditing and conducting trials of antibiotic prophylaxis by providing a standardized method for assessing wound infection severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ASA classification: This classification assesses the physical status of patients before surgery but is not used for wound infection severity.

 

Option C. Glasgow score: This score evaluates the level of consciousness in trauma and critical care patients but is unrelated to wound infection.

 

Option D. APGAR: This scoring system assesses the health of newborns immediately after birth, not wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Southampton grading scale is a specific tool used for assessing the severity of wound infections, particularly useful in research and surveillance

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg


In India, Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is commonly used as an emergency contraceptive. This medication is effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation, thus preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 400 mcg: Incorrect. Misoprostol is used for medical abortion and does not serve as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg: Incorrect. Ethinyl estradiol is used in combined oral contraceptive pills, but it is not commonly used alone for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe regimen, which includes ethynyl estradiol, is less commonly used compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option C. Ulipristal 30 mg: Incorrect. Ulipristal acetate (30 mg) is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive, but it is not as widely available or commonly used in India as levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) HbsAg

 

  • Hepatitis B is endemic throughout the world
  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccines consist of HBsAg (Hepatitis B virus surface antigen).
  • These vaccines are created using large molecules obtained from the immunogenic parts of pathogens through recombinant DNA technology.
  • They contrast with fully inactivated whole-cell vaccines as they exclusively contain the antigenic elements of the pathogen.
  • These elements are essential for prompting a defensive immune reaction.

 

Vaccines for Hepatitis B:

 

  • Plasma derived vaccine:
    • Is formalin inactivated sub-unit vaccine
    • Is based on HBsAg
    • Derived from carriers of Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis B vaccine, dose schedule in adult (months) 0, 1, 6 months
  • rDNA yeast derived vaccine: Recombinant DNA vaccine (genetically engineered)

 

Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin: 

 

  • Required for immediate protection:
    • Surgeons, nurse, laboratory workers
    • Newborn infants of carrier mothers
    • Sexual contacts of acute Hepatitis B patients
    • Ideally administered within 6 hours (not later than 48 hours)

  • Dose: 0.05–0.07 mL/kg, 2 doses 30 days apart

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

 

Anti Hbc Ab are produced against Hepatitis B infection. IgM is produced early and IgG later. Production of antibodies(A) is seen to correspond to gradual reduction of surface, envelop antigens.

 

 

Person recovering from acute infection may have negative anti HbS levels with low HbsAg levels. This is called window period where there is a lag between development of antiHbS and HbsAg levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBe Ab: These antibodies against the hepatitis B e antigen generally signify lower levels of viral replication. They are not represented at the marked point in the graph.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs Ab: These antibodies indicate recovery and immunity and typically appear after the disappearance of HBsAg, which occurs later than the timeframe shown for the marked serological marker.

 

Option D. HBsAg: This is the earliest detectable viral antigen to appear in the blood following infection but declines as Anti-HBc Ab and later Anti-HBs appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBc antibodies are crucial in diagnosing hepatitis B infection, as they appear early after exposure and persist throughout the infection. They are typically seen during the "window period" when HBsAg starts to wane and before Anti-HBs becomes detectable, indicating the body's initial immune response to the infection.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Hepatology/Viral hepatitis/ chap 339/

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic hypermutation

 

Affinity maturation is a process that occurs in B cells during an immune response, leading to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for their antigen. This process is primarily driven by somatic hypermutation (SHM).

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM): This involves the introduction of point mutations at a high rate in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells. These mutations occur in the DNA encoding the variable regions of both heavy and light chains of the antibody molecule.
  • Selection for High Affinity: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded. Those with mutations that increase the affinity of the antibody for its antigen are positively selected and proliferate, whereas B cells with lower affinity or non-functional antibodies are eliminated.
  • Result: This process leads to the production of high-affinity antibodies over time, enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotype Switching: Also known as class switch recombination, this process changes the antibody isotype (e.g., from IgM to IgG) but does not directly affect the antigen-binding affinity.

 

Option C. mRNA Splicing: This process involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA, but it is not involved in affinity maturation.

 

Option D. VDJ Rearrangement: This process generates the initial diversity of the antigen receptor repertoire by recombining variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments. It occurs before exposure to antigen and does not contribute to the increased affinity seen in affinity maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affinity maturation, which results in the production of high-affinity antibodies, is primarily due to somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled with selective survival and proliferation of B cells producing high-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule which are re-opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.

 

In Modified Young's operation, partial closure of the nostril is done to avoid discomfort.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasomotor rhinitis - Typically managed with medications such as antihistamines and nasal sprays; surgery is not a standard treatment.

 

Option C. Invasive aspergillosis - Treatment involves antifungal medications; surgical debridement may be necessary but does not involve closing the nostrils.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis - Managed with allergy medications, immunotherapy, and avoiding allergens; surgery is not indicated for occluding nostrils.

 

Educational Objective:


Young's operation is a unique surgical technique reserved for severe cases of atrophic rhinitis where other treatments have failed. This procedure helps in restoring the normal function and structure of the nasal mucosa by temporarily occluding the nostrils to allow healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a history of increasing muscle weakness over the last several months. She complains of difficulty performing daily activities such as climbing stairs and lifting objects due to fatigue. Physical examination reveals significant proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory tests show elevated muscle enzymes, including creatine kinase and aldolase. The physician notes specific skin findings that raise suspicion for a diagnosis of an inflammatory muscle disorder. Which of the following skin findings is most specific for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gottron’s papules

 

Gottron’s papules are a characteristic and specific sign seen in juvenile dermatomyositis. These violaceous, flat-topped, inflammatory papules are typically found on the extensor surfaces, particularly over the knuckles, proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints. They are pathognomonic for juvenile dermatomyositis and serve as a hallmark feature that helps confirm the diagnosis. The presence of these papules, along with muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes, distinguishes juvenile dermatomyositis from other conditions with overlapping symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discoid rash: This rash is typically seen in chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus and presents as scaly plaques, which are not specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Vesicular rash: Vesicular rashes, characterized by fluid-filled blisters, are more common in viral infections and are not associated with juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Erythematous nodules: These nodules, such as those seen in erythema nodosum, are red, painful lesions usually found on the lower extremities and are unrelated to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:


Gottron’s papules are the most specific and pathognomonic sign of juvenile dermatomyositis, appearing as violaceous, flat-topped papules on the extensor surfaces of the fingers. Recognizing these lesions is critical for diagnosing juvenile dermatomyositis and differentiating it from other autoimmune or inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

 

The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

 

Toxic megacolon is a severe condition characterized by acute colonic distension and systemic toxicity. It is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. Patients with toxic megacolon can present with high fever, abdominal pain, and a history of bloody diarrhea, which aligns with the patient's symptoms in this case. The abdominal X-ray shows transverse colonic dilation > 6 cm, which is a characteristic finding in toxic megacolon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a condition in which a portion of the bowel twists on itself, leading to obstruction and ischemia. While it can cause abdominal pain, it typically does not present with the same systemic symptoms seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Ogilvie syndrome: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is characterized by marked colonic dilation without a mechanical obstruction. It can cause abdominal pain and distension but does not typically present with a history of bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestine. While it can be seen on imaging studies, it is not a specific diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.

 

A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycogen synthase

 

Glycogen synthase: This is the correct answer. Glycogen synthase is responsible for synthesizing glycogen from glucose. A deficiency in glycogen synthase would result in the inability to produce glycogen, which aligns with the liver examination findings of no glycogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease or glycogen storage disease type V) primarily affects skeletal muscle glycogen metabolism. Symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, and exercise intolerance.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme deficiency (Cori's disease or glycogen storage disease type III) presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and growth retardation. The liver would still contain glycogen, although with an abnormal structure.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke's disease or glycogen storage disease type I) is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hepatomegaly, Renomegaly. In this case, glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be broken down efficiently into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen synthase is a key enzyme involved in glycogenesis, the process of synthesizing glycogen, which serves as a storage form of glucose in the liver and muscles. Glycogen synthase catalyzes the addition of glucose molecules to the growing glycogen chain by creating alpha-1,4-glycosidic linkages between glucose units. This enzyme is regulated by various factors, including insulin, which promotes glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase.

 

Mutations or dysregulation of glycogen synthase can lead to Glycogen Storage Disease 0 (GSD 0), a disorder resulting from mutations in the GYS2 gene encoding liver glycogen synthase. C/f include fasting hypoglycemia, hunger between meals, hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and other metabolic abnormalities due to impaired glycogen synthesis.

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

 

The above shows the compliance diagram of lung

 

Compliance Diagram of the Lungs

 

It is a diagram relating lung volume changes to changes in transpulmonary pressure. 

 

The characteristics of the compliance diagram are determined

 

The surfactant, secreted by type II pneumocytes, reduces surface tension in alveoli.


During inspiration, alveoli expand, decreasing the surfactant concentration, which leads to increased surface tension, requiring more pressure to keep alveoli open.


During expiration, alveoli deflate, increasing surfactant concentration, thus decreasing surface tension, and requiring less pressure.


This asymmetry in surface tension during inspiration and expiration contributes to the difference in the trajectory (hysteresis) of the curve
 

The tissue elastic forces tending to cause collapse of the air-filled lung represent only about one third of the total lung elasticity, whereas the fluid-air surface tension forces in the alveoli represent about two thirds.

 

Thus, a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway due to surface tension at the air-water interface due to surfactant deficit, than to keep an open airway from closing, reflecting abundant surfactant.

 

 

 

Surfactant concentration increases during expiration (smaller alveoli → surfactant molecules closer), lowering surface tension and making expiration easier compared to inspiration. This is the correct cause of hysteresis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration: Incorrect, as this refers to the pressure gradients that drive airflow but does not directly cause the loop shape differences seen in the compliance graph.

 

Option C. Airway resistance can be higher during expiration due to dynamic airway compression, especially in obstructive diseases.

However, the P-V loop is a static curve, plotted during slow, controlled breathing or when airflow has ceased — not during forced maneuvers — so airway resistance has minimal impact on this loop. This might be more relevant to flow-volume loops, not pressure-volume loops

 

Option D. This is true physiologically — inspiration involves active muscle contraction, and expiration is usually passive at rest. But this does not explain the hysteresis in the pressure-volume loop.  The loop reflects lung compliance and surface tension, not the energy used for breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The difference between inspiratory and expiratory pressure-volume loops (hysteresis) is primarily due to dynamic changes in surfactant concentration, which alters surface tension between inspiration and expiration. Understanding this helps explain lung compliance behavior and the role of surfactant in stabilizing alveoli.

choices.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh
Referral centre for 2- 3 primary health centers
No sub-district and district hospitals present in the area
Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

 

An Urban Community Health Center (U-CHC) is designed to provide inpatient care and other health services in urban areas. According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines, the requirements for U-CHCs are as follows:

 

  • 30-50 bedded U-CHC providing inpatient care in cities (>1 per 500,000 population)
  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air


Severe COVID-19 is characterized by a significant drop in oxygen saturation. An SpO2 of less than 85% on room air indicates severe hypoxemia.

 

Any SpO2 of less than 90% indicate severe COVID and 90-93% indicates moderate COVID

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RR >24/min: Indicates moderate, not severe, COVID-19. RR>30/min indicate severe COVID
 

Option B. MAP 70 mmHg: Does not specifically indicate severe COVID-19. Hemodynamic instability i.e. MAP <65 OR 65 or above with vasopressors indicates severe COVID. 
 

Option C. Lung infiltrates >42% on CT: Not a specific criterion for COVID-19 severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of seizure disorder has been successfully managed on phenytoin for several years. Recently, he was diagnosed with peptic ulcers and prescribed sucralfate to be taken four times daily. He experiences worsening seizure control shortly after starting the new medication. His physician suspects a drug interaction between phenytoin and sucralfate. To ensure optimal absorption and effectiveness of phenytoin, what should be the minimum duration of time between the administration of these two medications?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 hours

 

Sucralfate is composed of aluminum octosulphate of sucrose, which, in the acidic environment of the stomach, polymerizes into a viscous gel that adheres to the ulcer base and can persist for up to 6 hours. This viscous layer can interfere with the absorption of several drugs, including phenytoin, by binding to them in the gastrointestinal tract, thus reducing their effectiveness. To avoid this interaction, it is recommended to separate the administration of phenytoin and sucralfate by at least 2 hours. This timing allows sufficient absorption of phenytoin before sucralfate is taken, thereby minimizing the risk of reduced drug efficacy due to binding interference.

 

Educational Objective:


When administering phenytoin and sucralfate together, it is crucial to separate their intake by at least 2 hours to prevent sucralfate from interfering with phenytoin absorption. This ensures that the antiepileptic drug maintains its efficacy without being hindered by the ulcer-protective effects of sucralfate.

questions.text: The best method to measure HbA1c is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ion exchange chromatography

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood

glucose concentration. Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6–8 weeks.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

 

Ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on charge differences between HbA1c and other hemoglobins. It is considered as a gold standard for HbA1c analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoelectric focusing:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their isoelectric points.
  • Limitation: Not commonly used for HbA1c measurement due to complexity and lower specificity for glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography:

  • Function: Uses specific binding interactions to separate molecules.
  • Limitation: While effective in some contexts, it is not the most common method for routine HbA1c measurement.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their size and charge under an electric field.
  • Limitation: Not as specific or reliable for HbA1c measurement compared to ion-exchange HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ion-exchange chromatography is considered the gold standard for measuring HbA1c due to its high accuracy and ability to separate HbA1c from other hemoglobin variants based on charge differences.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

For a 60-year-old patient with diabetes and hypertension (BP 150/90 mmHg), it is critical to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Current guidelines, including the 2023 European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines, recommend initiating antihypertensive therapy in such patients due to the high risk of cardiovascular events. Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is an appropriate choice for initial antihypertensive therapy in diabetic patients. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is well-tolerated, without negatively impacting glycemic control. Ideally, an ACE inhibitor or ARB would be preferred, but if not available, a calcium channel blocker like amlodipine is a suitable alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol: Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not first-line therapy for hypertension unless there is a specific indication such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, or angina. Beta-blockers are not the preferred initial treatment for hypertensive diabetics.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modifications are important, they are insufficient alone for managing hypertension in a diabetic patient, who is at high cardiovascular risk.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Prazosin, an alpha-blocker, is not typically used as first-line therapy for hypertension. It may be used in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but offers no additional advantage in this context and may cause orthostatic hypotension, worsening dizziness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive diabetic patients, it is essential to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Amlodipine is an appropriate choice for initial therapy in this context.

questions.text: A gynecologist performs a hysterectomy for endometrial carcinoma. Despite the adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. The gynecologist is not held responsible under? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical maloccurence 

 

The gynecologist cannot be held responsible for the above act under medical maloccurence.

 

Medical maloccurence/Inevitable Accident: 

 

  • It is defined as an unfavorable outcome, but not resulting from malpractice.
  • Despite giving best treatment patient may fail to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions of the drug leading to temporary or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurence/inevitable accident.
  • If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defense against malpractice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: This legal term refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation, leading to a result that might not have been foreseeable. This does not apply here as the injury was directly related to the surgical procedure, not an external unrelated event.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor: Latin for "the thing speaks for itself," this doctrine applies in cases where the injury would not typically occur without negligence. This option would suggest a presumption of negligence because such injuries usually do not occur without a breach in the standard of care. However, the context given indicates precautions were taken, so this is not the best answer.

 

Option D. Physician error: This implies a mistake made by the physician that could lead to legal liability. In this scenario, it was noted that all standard precautions were followed, thus excluding this option as the appropriate answer given that no specific error or negligence was cited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical maloccurence is critical to understand that not all adverse outcomes in medicine result from negligence. Some are inherent risks of medical procedures despite the highest standards of care. Recognizing this helps in managing patient expectations and can protect healthcare providers in cases where complications arise despite proper precautions.

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progesterone

 

Post ovulation, there is a significant rise in progesterone levels, which is crucial for the transformation of the endometrium into a secretory phase. This phase is essential for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation of an embryo.

 

Phases of the Menstrual Cycle:

 

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days):
    • The shedding of the endometrial lining occurs if there is no pregnancy.
  2. Follicular Phase (10 - 14 days):
    • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
    • Estrogen levels rise, leading to the proliferation of the endometrium.
  3. Ovulation (14th day):
    • Luteinizing hormone (LH) surge leads to the release of an ovum from the dominant follicle.
  4. Luteal Phase (14 - 28 days):
    • The corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone.
    • Progesterone causes the endometrium to develop secretory glands and prepare for implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone: LH is primarily involved in triggering ovulation and the formation of the corpus luteum.

 

Option B. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone: FSH is crucial for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles during the follicular phase.

 

Option D. Estrogen: Estrogen is significant during the follicular phase for the proliferation of the endometrium but is not the main hormone acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone is the hormone responsible for preparing the endometrium for implantation during the post-ovulatory phase.

 

Ref: Page no 94, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The organism with following life cycle is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The given life cycle is of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Infective form - Filariform larvae

 

Natural host – Man

 

Mode of infection – penetration of skin by filariform larvae and autoinfection


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans through skin penetration by its larvae.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides is a roundworm that infects humans through ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis is a pinworm that infects humans through ingestion of its eggs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis involves skin penetration by filariform larvae and autoinfection.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the image shown below?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxa vara

 

  • Coxa vara is a term used to describe a reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.
  • It may be congenital/acquired (growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis) or acquired (secondary to various other pathologies).
  • The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara.

 

 

  • This is coxa vara resulting from some unknown growth anomaly at the upper femoral epiphysis.
  • It is noticed as a painless limp in a child who has just started walking.
  • In severe cases, shortening of the leg may be obvious.
  • On examination, abduction and internal rotation of the hip are limited and the leg is short.
  • X-rays will show a reduction in neck-shaft angle.
  • The epiphyseal plate may be too vertical.
  • There may be a separate triangle of bone in the inferior portion of the metaphysis, called Fairbank’s triangle.

 

 

  • Treatment: Subtrochanteric corrective osteotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxa magna. Coxa magna is the asymmetrical, circumferential enlargement and deformation of the femoral head and neck. It is seen in Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, transient synovitis of the hip, developmental dysplasia of the hip, trauma, septic arthritis/osteomyelitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

 

 

Option B. Coxa valga. Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow acetabular angles and femoral head subluxation. Bilateral coxa valga can be seen in cerebral palsy, turner syndrome. Unilateral occurs due to trauma causing growth plate arrest. Angle more than 140° is considered as coxa valga.

 

 

 

Option D. Coxa Saltans. It is a condition characterized by a snapping sensation in the hip that comprises of 3 entities: external snapping hip (caused by iliotibial tract sliding over greater trochanter), internal snapping hip (caused by iliopsoas tendon sliding over femoral head, iliopectineal ridge, lesser trochanter, and iliopsoas bursa), and intra-articular snapping hip (caused by loose body in hip/labral tears). It is common in athletes and dancers in their teens or twenties. X-ray usually appears normal. MRI may show inflamed bursa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows coxa vara i.e., reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Methemoglobinemia

 

The patient presenting with a brownish hue in the blood, coupled with a history of chronic stable angina, points towards methemoglobinemia. Patients with chronic stable angina are often on nitrate therapy, which is a known risk factor for developing methemoglobinemia.

 

Methemoglobinemia occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe²⁺) state to the ferric (Fe³⁺) state, which is unable to bind oxygen effectively. This results in reduced oxygen delivery to tissues, leading to symptoms such as fatigue and cyanosis. The brownish hue of the blood, often described as chocolate-colored, is characteristic of methemoglobinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxyhemoglobinemia: Carboxyhemoglobinemia is caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, typically associated with exposure to fire or automobile exhaust. The blood in this condition has a cherry red color, not brownish.

 

Option B. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is a form of anemia where the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells. It does not cause a brownish hue in the blood.

 

Option D. Sulfhemoglobinemia: Sulfhemoglobinemia results from the incorporation of sulfur into hemoglobin, leading to a greenish or bluish color of the blood, rather than brownish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A brownish hue in the blood, especially in a patient on nitrate therapy, is indicative of methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, impairing its ability to carry oxygen effectively.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

 

  • The above image shows the seeds of Semicarpus anacardium
  • Identification: Black, heart-shaped seeds with a rough projection at the base
  • Active principles: bhilawanol and semicarpol.
  • Common name: Marking nut
  • Uses of the juice:
    • To produce an artificial bruise.
    • Juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin: Ricin is a highly toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

 

Option C. Abrin: Abrin is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

 

Option D. Calotropin: Calotropin is a cardiac glycoside found in the milkweed plant (Calotropis gigantea).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active principle of the marking nut (Semicarpus anacardium) is Bhilawanol, used in traditional practices for its staining and toxic properties.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female domestic worker reports to the forensic unit following an alleged sexual assault by her employer. During the forensic examination, white stains are observed on her clothing. The stains are subjected to Barberio's test to detect specific seminal components. Which of the following substances is identified by Barberio’s test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spermine

 

Barberio’s test is a forensic microchemical test used to detect spermine, a prostatic component of semen. This test is performed by adding an alcoholic solution of picric acid to the dried seminal stain. The reaction produces yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, which are characteristic and identifiable under a microscope. Spermine is a specific marker of seminal fluid, especially secreted from the prostate gland, making this test valuable in forensic investigations to support the presence of semen in cases of sexual assault.

 

 

Tests for Seminal Stains

 

  1. Presumptive Tests for Seminal Stains:
    • Fluorescence under UV Light: Semen may exhibit a characteristic fluorescence when exposed to UV light, aiding in preliminary identification.
    • Microchemical Tests:
      • Florence Test: Detects choline crystals, indicating the presence of seminal fluid.
      • Barberio’s Test: Identifies spermine phosphate crystals, another marker of semen.
  2. Confirmatory Tests for Semen:
    • Microscopic Detection of Spermatozoa: The most definitive test, confirming the presence of semen by visualizing intact sperm cells under a microscope.
    • Acid Phosphatase Test: Highly sensitive test that detects the enzyme acid phosphatase, which is produced in high concentrations by the prostate gland and is abundant in semen.
    • Creatine Phosphokinase (CPK) Test: Detects CPK, an enzyme specifically associated with spermatozoa, providing further confirmation of seminal fluid.
    • Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) Test: Identifies PSA, a protein produced by the prostate, which is a reliable marker for confirming the presence of semen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is an enzyme produced by the prostate gland and is present in high concentrations in semen. It is commonly used in the acid phosphatase test, a presumptive test for semen, but it is not the target of Barberio’s test.

 

Option C. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA): PSA is another protein secreted by the prostate gland and used as a confirmatory marker for semen. PSA testing is not part of Barberio’s test but serves as an alternative confirmatory test.

 

Option D. Creatine phosphokinase: Creatine phosphokinase is an enzyme found in various tissues, including spermatozoa, and plays a role in energy metabolism. It is used in specific tests for semen but is not detected by Barberio’s test.

 

Educational Objective:


Barberio’s test is a forensic method that identifies spermine, a component of seminal fluid secreted by the prostate gland, by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate with picric acid. This test is useful in detecting semen in forensic cases, particularly when investigating sexual assault.

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements: (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
  2. Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
  3. NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
  4. All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3 correct

 

Anticoagulants are indicated for ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation. NOACs are contraindicated in patients with prosthetic valves due to a lack of evidence on their efficacy and safety in this population.

 

Other Options:

 

1. NOACs are not used for moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

4. Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are used for rate control but not universally applicable.

 

Educational Objective:


Anticoagulants are used for ischemic stroke in AF, and NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves.

choices.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine. (AIIMS May 2019)

 

Reason: Even after completion of ATT, there can be neurological abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis, accounting for 50% of cases followed by hip (15%) and knee (10%).
  • Any level of the spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common followed by lumbar > upper dorsal > cervical > sacral region.
  • Types:

 

 

  • Clinical features: Pain, stiffness, cold abscess formation, paraplegia, deformity, fever, weight loss.
  • Imaging:
    1. Plain radiograph:
      • Reduction of disc space
      • Vertebral body destruction
      • Paravertebral abscess
      • Widening of mediastinum
    2. CT scan: 
      • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
    3. MRI: 
      • It is the investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
      • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.
    4. Biopsy: 
      • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: Patient has no neural complaint clinician elicits increased reflexes.
    • Stage 2: Patient has weakness but can walk with support.
    • Stage 3: Patient is non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%.
    • Stage 4: Patient has bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%.
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India.
    • Patient is treated by antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist  then he needs to be operated.
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB, the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement.
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks or
    4. Surgical options for most of the cases are: anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
    5. Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
    6. Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.

 

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cladosporium

 

  • The dematiaceous (brown-pigment) fungi are a large and heterogenous group of molds that cause a wide range of diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.
  • Among the more important human pathogens are Alternaria species, Bipolaris species, Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) bantiana, Curvularia species, Exophiala species, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Madurella species, Phialophora species, Scedosporium prolificans, Scytalidium dimidiatum, and Wangiella dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor species: Incorrect Mucor species are not dematiaceous fungi. They are non-pigmented (hyaline) fungi that cause mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
 

Option B. Aspergillus niger: Incorrect Aspergillus niger is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a black mold, but it does not belong to the group of dematiaceous fungi. It is a common cause of aspergillosis.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cladosporium is a dematiaceous fungus, characterized by its dark pigmentation due to melanin in its cell walls, and it is associated with various diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hair growth

 

  • Hair growth (Pubarche): The development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.
  • Estrogen effects: Estrogen plays a crucial role in various aspects of puberty, including:
    • Breast development (thelarche)
