    • Development of internal genitalia
    • Menarche
    • Regulation of growth spurt
    • Epiphyseal closure
    • Cervical mucus plug formation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical mucus secretion: Estrogen is responsible for the secretion of cervical mucus.

 

Option C. Vaginal cornification: Estrogen promotes the cornification (maturation) of the vaginal epithelium.

 

Option D. Menstruation: Estrogen is critical in regulating the menstrual cycle and the onset of menarche.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hair growth during puberty is mediated by testosterone, not estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for breast development, internal genitalia development, menarche, growth spurt regulation, epiphyseal closure, and cervical mucus secretion.

 

Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Tuberculoid leprosy has a higher remission rate compared to indeterminate leprosy.
Approximately 50% of individuals exposed to Mycobacterium leprae develop clinical symptoms.
Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.
Lepromatous leprosy frequently undergoes spontaneous healing without medical intervention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from a remote village presents to the clinic with gradually worsening skin lesions that have been present for over a year. He reports that some areas of his skin have lost sensation, making it difficult to differentiate between hot and cold objects. On examination, there are multiple hypopigmented patches with partial loss of sensation. The patient has not received any prior treatment. A nasal smear shows acid-fast bacilli. The clinician discusses the possible progression and spontaneous remission rates of the disease if left untreated. Which of the following statements correctly describes the likelihood of spontaneous healing in untreated leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Indeterminate leprosy often presents with nonspecific, hypopigmented lesions and mild sensory loss. It is the most unstable form of leprosy and may progress to more defined types such as tuberculoid or lepromatous leprosy, depending on the patient’s immune response. However, approximately 75% of cases of indeterminate leprosy spontaneously remit without progressing further, a rate significantly higher than that observed in tuberculoid leprosy. Tuberculoid leprosy is relatively more stable and less likely to undergo spontaneous healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy has a higher remission rate compared to indeterminate leprosy: This statement is incorrect. Indeterminate leprosy has a significantly higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy, which is more stable and less prone to self-resolution.

 

Option B. Approximately 50% of individuals exposed to Mycobacterium leprae develop clinical symptoms: This is incorrect. In reality, only 10-20% of individuals exposed to the bacterium develop clinical leprosy due to the majority having sufficient immunity to prevent disease progression.

 

Option D. Lepromatous leprosy frequently undergoes spontaneous healing without medical intervention: Lepromatous leprosy, characterized by widespread skin involvement and a high bacterial load, rarely remits without treatment and typically requires aggressive medical management.

 

Educational Objective:


Indeterminate leprosy is characterized by higher rates of spontaneous remission compared to other forms of leprosy, such as tuberculoid leprosy. Recognizing the natural history of untreated leprosy is crucial for understanding its clinical course and potential for self-resolution.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising. What is the likely underlying condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypercortisolism

 

Hypercortisolism, also known as Cushing's syndrome, is characterized by an excess of cortisol in the body. The clinical features of Cushing's syndrome include weight gain, particularly in the face, neck, and trunk, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae (stretch marks), and easy bruising. These symptoms are a result of the catabolic effects of cortisol on various tissues.

 

  • Weight Gain: Cortisol promotes the deposition of fat in specific areas, leading to central obesity.
  • Proximal Muscle Weakness: Cortisol has catabolic effects on muscle tissue, leading to muscle wasting and weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles.
  • Purple Striae: Cortisol weakens the skin by breaking down collagen, leading to the formation of purple striae.
  • Easy Bruising: Cortisol reduces the ability of blood vessels to repair themselves, causing increased bruising.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: This condition involves an excess of thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as weight loss, increased appetite, heat intolerance, and hyperactivity. It does not typically cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: This condition involves an excess of parathyroid hormone, leading to hypercalcemia, bone pain, kidney stones, and abdominal pain. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Hyperaldosteronism: This condition involves an excess of aldosterone, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's syndrome, or hypercortisolism, is characterized by weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising due to the catabolic effects of excess cortisol.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Gierke's disease

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Von Gierke’s disease (type I)

 

Salient features of Von Gierke’s Disease –

 

  • It is the most common type of glycogen storage disease.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is deficient.
  • Fasting hypoglycemia that does not respond to stimulation by adrenaline. The glucose cannot be released from liver during overnight fasting .
  • Clinical Features: Hyperlipidemia, lactic acidosis and ketosis.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate is accumulated, so it is channeled to HMP shunt pathway producing more ribose and more purine nucleotides.
  • Purines are then catabolized to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia
  • Glycogen gets deposited in liver. Massive liver enlargement may lead to cirrhosis.
  • Children usually die in early childhood.
  • Renomegaly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pompe's disease: This is a glycogen storage disease characterized by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase. It primarily affects muscles and causes cardiomegaly but does not present with the same biochemical profile as Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option C. McArdle's disease: This is characterized by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase and primarily affects muscle metabolism, leading to muscle cramps and myoglobinuria after exercise, but not the described biochemical abnormalities or hepatomegaly.

 

Option D. Cori's disease: Also known as Forbes disease or glycogen storage disease type III, it is caused by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme. While it can cause hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, it does not present with the specific profile of ketonemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperlipidemia seen in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement:
    • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The older definition of active labor was at 4 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) now defines active labor as beginning at more than 6 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • Complete effacement indicates that the cervix has thinned out, which is a key indicator of active labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: This indicates that the fetal head is still high in the pelvis and not yet engaged. It does not determine active labor.

 

Option B. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This frequency and duration of contractions are not sufficient to determine active labor. Active labor typically involves regular, strong contractions lasting 45-60 seconds and occurring every 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes can occur during labor, it is not a definitive indicator of active labor. Cervical dilation and effacement are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active labor is determined by more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation with complete effacement, according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Ref: Page no 138, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor

 

When a person changes posture from supine to standing, the immediate effect is a decrease in mean arterial pressure (MAP) due to gravity causing blood to pool in the lower extremities. This results in decreased venous return and cardiac output and decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase: Incorrect. The vagal (parasympathetic) output decreases when standing to allow an increase in heart rate and cardiac output.

 

Option C. Mesenteric vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Although mesenteric vasoconstriction occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is not the immediate response; the initial response is the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Option D. Increase cardiac contractility: Incorrect. While increased cardiac contractility occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is a subsequent response following the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate response when a person changes posture from supine to standing is a decrease in baroreceptor firing due to a reduction in mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being caught in a bomb blast at a railway station. He has multiple small puncture wounds on his left chest and several small abrasions scattered across his body. He is conscious, and his vital signs are stable. On examination, there are no signs of penetrating deep trauma, but numerous superficial injuries are visible. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for these injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary blast injuries

 

Secondary blast injuries occur due to shrapnel, debris, or fragments from the explosive device or the surrounding environment, causing penetrating trauma, lacerations, and abrasions. These injuries result from ballistic trauma when high-velocity objects strike the body, often leading to multiple small puncture wounds, abrasions, and other forms of superficial injuries, as seen in this patient. This type of injury is the most common in blast scenarios and is primarily due to flying missiles, such as fragments and debris propelled by the explosion.

 

Classification of Blast Injuries:

 

  1. Primary blast injuries are caused solely by the blast wave affecting gas-filled organs such as the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and ears. These injuries are typically internal, such as ruptured eardrums or pulmonary barotrauma, rather than superficial wounds.
  2. Secondary blast injuries are the result of fragmentation wounds from the explosive device or the surrounding environment. These primarily include ballistic trauma from flying shrapnel, causing puncture wounds, lacerations, and abrasions, which align with the patient's presentation.
  3. Tertiary blast injuries result from the displacement of the victim or environmental structures. These injuries are predominantly blunt traumatic injuries caused by the forceful impact of the body being thrown against hard surfaces, leading to fractures and contusions, not superficial puncture wounds.
  4. Quaternary explosive injuries encompass other injuries related to explosions, such as burns, inhalation of toxic fumes, and exposure to radiologic or chemical contamination, which present differently from the patient's described symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary blast injuries: These injuries occur directly due to the blast wave and typically affect gas-filled structures within the body, presenting as internal trauma rather than puncture wounds or abrasions.

 

Option C. Tertiary blast injuries: These injuries involve blunt force trauma caused by the victim being thrown by the blast, often resulting in contusions, fractures, and other blunt injuries rather than the superficial wounds described.

 

Option D. Quaternary blast injuries: Quaternary injuries include burns, exposure to toxins, and contamination but do not involve the puncture wounds and abrasions caused by flying debris.

 

Educational Objective:


Secondary blast injuries are caused by fragments and debris propelled by an explosion, leading to penetrating wounds, lacerations, and abrasions. The classification of blast injuries

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The clinical presentation of severe headache, high fever, papilloedema, and nuchal rigidity, combined with the Gram stain results, is highly indicative of meningococcal meningitis, caused by Neisseria meningitidis. The image from the Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci supports this diagnosis. Neisseria meningitidis is known for appearing as gram-negative diplococci, often resembling kidney beans, and typically found within white blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

 

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus and typically presents with tumbling motility in liquid media, not as diplococci.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis - Intracellular gram-negative diplococci in gram staining.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human genome project?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It took 2 years to discover

 

  • Explanation: Option D is false. The Human Genome Project did not take only 2 years to complete. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade. The official launch of the project was in 1990, and a working draft of the human genome was announced in 2000. The project was completed in 2003.
  • Relevance: This statement is false, and the actual timeline of the Human Genome Project demonstrates that it was a multi-year, collaborative effort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collaboration of Many Countries:

 

  • Explanation: The Human Genome Project was indeed a collaborative effort involving many countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others. It aimed to map and sequence the entire human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects the international nature of the project.

 

Option B. 20,000 Total Genes Were Identified :

 

  • Explanation: During the Human Genome Project, it was estimated that there are approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes in the human genome. This estimate is relatively accurate, considering the complexity of the human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects one of the significant achievements of the HGP.

 

Option C. It Uses Modern Sequencing Techniques:

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The project initially started with Sanger sequencing, which was state-of-the-art at the time.
  • Towards the end and afterward, next-generation sequencing (NGS) evolved, further enhancing genome studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Human genome project started in 1990 and completed with sequence of Y chromosome this year in 2022. So, it took > 2 decades. This was a collaborative project spread across many labs in different countries across world. Approximately 22000 genes were identified in entire Human genome using High throughput Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) techniques.

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 98

questions.text: Fructosamine (which is used for assessing long term glycemic control in a person with hemolysis) is a glycated product of: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

Fructosamine is a compound formed when glucose binds to serum albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood. This glycated product provides an indicator of long-term glycemic control because it reflects the average blood glucose levels over the previous 2 to 3 weeks. Since it is primarily formed from the glycation of albumin, option d (Albumin) is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycosaminoglycan refers to a different type of compound, glycosaminoglycans, which are long, linear polysaccharides found in connective tissues.

 

Option B. Urea is a waste product removed by the kidneys and is not involved in fructosamine formation.

 

Option C. Fructose is a sugar but is not directly related to the formation of fructosamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose can be attached to proteins, albumin, and also to RBCs forming HbA1c. Fructosamine is term used for all the glycated proteins including glycated albumin.

 

 

 

In hemolysis patient, HbA1c analysis cannot be done because it will be falsely decreased due to damage to RBCs and loss of hemoglobin. So, fructosamine determination is used for these patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

Lingual Nerve: This is the branch of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It runs close to the submandibular gland and is therefore at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Sensory Distribution: Provides general sensory (pain, temperature, touch) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. (Note: Taste sensation for this region is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, which joins the lingual nerve for a short course.)

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

 

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerve to Mylohyoid: This nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3). It descends on the medial surface of the mandible in the mylohyoid groove.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in the elevation of the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth during swallowing and speech.

 

Option B. Inferior Alveolar Nerve: It's a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It enters the mandibular foramen and runs through the mandibular canal.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Does not directly supply any muscles.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the mandibular teeth, lower lip, and chin.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal Nerve (12th Cranial Nerve): This cranial nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and supplies the muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies almost all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vagus nerve).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Tongue deviation to the side of the lesion due to weakened tongue muscles on that side. If you asked the patient to protrude their tongue, it would point towards the side of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What importance does the point labelled as 'C' hold? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Onset of symptoms

 

  • The given image depicts timeline of natural history of disease in an individual over time, in which the point labelled C denotes the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

This is a typical picture of Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causing pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by 4Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dermatitis (Casal’s Necklace) dementia and Death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pellagra

 

  1. Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  2. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  3. Malabsorption
  4. Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

questions.text: Most common hernia in females (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

The most common type of hernia in females is the inguinal hernia, and specifically, the indirect inguinal hernia. This can be confusing because femoral hernias are indeed more common in females compared to males, but the indirect inguinal hernia remains the most prevalent overall in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal hernia: Incorrect. While inguinal hernias are common, the direct inguinal hernia is less common than the indirect inguinal hernia in both males and females.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias are more frequently seen in females compared to males, but they are not the most common type of hernia in females overall.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia: Incorrect. Obturator hernias are rare and not the most common type of hernia in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In females, the most common type of hernia is the indirect inguinal hernia, despite femoral hernias being more common in females compared to males.

 

Incidence of Hernia in Females: Indirect inguinal Hernia > Direct inguinal Hernia > Femoral hernia

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

 

FAT EMBOLISM

  • Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours – think of fat embolism!
  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow.
  • Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Salient Features:
    • Presence of fat globules in pulmonary circulation.
    • Precipitated by physical trauma such as fracture of long bones, soft tissue trauma, and burns.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Clinical signs and symptoms develop after a asymptomatic latent period of about 12 - 48 hours.
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea.
      • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation.
      • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder.
  • Diagnosis:
    • FES is distinct from the presence of fat emboli.
    • Symptoms usually occur 1-3 days after a traumatic injury and are predominantly pulmonary (shortness of breath, hypoxemia), neurological (agitation, delirium, or coma), dermatological (petechial rash), and hematological (anemia, low platelets).
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood.
    • If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation.
    • Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg.
    • O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax. A pneumothorax is a collection of air outside the lung but within the pleural cavity. It occurs when air accumulates between the parietal and visceral pleurae inside the chest. The air accumulation can apply pressure on the lung and make it collapse. Causes of traumatic pneumothorax are penetrating or blunt trauma, rib fracture, diving or flying. While it can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur specifically after femur fracture fixation unless there was a procedure complication.

 

Option B. Pleural effusion. Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in between the parietal and visceral pleura, called the pleural cavity. It can occur by itself or can be the result of surrounding parenchymal disease like infection, malignancy, or inflammatory conditions. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to occur suddenly after femur fracture fixation unless there are other complicating factors.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure. Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by inefficient myocardial performance, resulting in compromised blood supply to the body. CHF results from any disorder that impairs ventricular filling or ejection of blood to the systemic circulation. Patients usually present with fatigue and dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and systemic or pulmonary congestion. While congestive heart failure can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur suddenly after a femur fracture fixation unless the patient has pre-existing heart conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fat embolism is the most common complication of femur fracture.
  • It usually presents 48 hours after the injury with breathlessness and low grade fever.
  • The patient  remains asymptomatic in the initial 12-48 hours.

questions.text:
The table provided illustrates a multivariate analysis assessing the relationship between the risk of blindness and various factors including age, literacy rate, place of residence, and gender. Which of the subsequent statements accurately interprets this data? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

 

  1. Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness.
  2. People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness.
  3. Risk of developing blindness increases with age.
  4. Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3 and 4

 

  • The correct statements drawn from the values given in the table are 3 and 4.
  • An odds ratio is a measure of the association between an exposure and an outcome. It represents the odds that an outcome will occur given a particular exposure in comparison to the odds of the outcome occurring in the absence of that exposure.

 

Statement 3: Risk of developing blindness increases with age.

 

  • Correct. The odds ratios increase with age categories, and all are statistically significant with p-values <0.001. This indicates that the risk of developing blindness increases with age.

 

Statement 4: Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.

 

  • Correct. The odds ratio for illiteracy is 1.2 with a p-value <0.01, indicating that illiteracy is associated with an increased risk of developing blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Statements 1 and 2 have an odds ratio of >1 and a statistically significant p-value, respectively. This implies that the cause increases the risk of disease and is a risk factor. However, these statements are incorrect due to the following reason: -

 

Statement 1: Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness is a false statement; since the odds ratio is <1, the female population will be at lesser risk of developing blindness than the male population.

 

Statement 2: People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness is also false; a p-value of >0.05 means that this association is not statistically significant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Odds ratio interpretation:

 

  • Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease.
  • Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective.
  • Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.

 

p-value interpretation:

 

  • p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant.
  • p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL. Arrange them in the right order? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Uterine tone assessment
  2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg)
  3. Exclude the presence of another fetus
  4. Controlled cord traction

 

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 4, 1

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of interventions aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The correct order of actions is:

 

3. Exclude the presence of another fetus: Ensure there is no additional fetus before administering any uterotonic.

 

2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg): Administer a uterotonic drug to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. It is given after the delivery of baby.

 

4. Controlled cord traction: Perform controlled traction on the umbilical cord to deliver the placenta.

 

1. Uterine tone assessment: assess the uterine tone every 15 minutes to detect uterine atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) should be followed in a specific order: exclude the presence of another fetus, administer a uterotonic, perform controlled cord traction, and then assess the uterine tone.
